title: Expose interface type for HTTP request options parameters

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

It would be nice for http requests if there was an exposed interface type for the options parameter rather than defining them in the method signatures directly. Example scenario is where I essentially want to decorate the base HttpClient service  - and I want to give it (almost) the full options API in general and forward that to the main client. It would be nicer if I could type it with something like `HttpRequestOptions` rather than copying the entire thing for each overload I want to potentially use. Simple scenario would be a service that decorates `HttpClient` to always use the same base/host when building the URL.

### Proposed solution

Ideally, define some interface along the lines of this:

```ts
type HttpRequestObserve = 'body' | 'events' | 'response';
type HttpRequestResponseType = 'arraybuffer' | 'blob' | 'json' | 'text';

export interface HttpRequestOptions<
  O extends HttpRequestObserve = HttpRequestObserve,
  R extends HttpRequestResponseType = HttpRequestResponseType
  > {
  headers?: HttpHeaders|{[header: string]: string | string[]},
  context?: HttpContext,
  observe?: O,
  params?: HttpParams|
    {[param: string]: string | number | boolean | ReadonlyArray<string|number|boolean>},
  reportProgress?: boolean,
  responseType?: R,
  withCredentials?: boolean,
}

```

Then signatures become as simple as:

```ts  
get<T>(url: string, options?: HttpRequestOptions<"body", "json">): Observable<T>;)
```

----

Added benefit is now client-code (clients of the angular/common library) can type anything they want to http options much easier.

I see the comment [here](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/df1652e7d747a698a87a162f18717618422f4a43/packages/common/http/src/client.ts#L22) references a `HttpRequestOptions` type but I don't see any other references to that type in the source code.

I would be willing to submit a PR but wanted to post issue to see thoughts first.

### Alternatives considered

Right now I have that interface defined in my projects.

title: Typed Form FormControl value cannot be initialized to null

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Even though type is 

`FormControl<string | null>`

initial value cannot be null, we get an error.  Is this behaviour on purpose?

```ts
  reservationForm: FormGroup<{
    name: FormControl<string | null>;
  }> = new FormBuilder().group({
    name: [null, Validators.required]

  });
```

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-zyp5eg?file=src/app/app.component.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Type 'FormGroup<{ name: FormControl<(control: AbstractControl<any, any>) => ValidationErrors>; }>' is not assignable to type 'FormGroup<{ name: FormControl<string>; }>'.
  Types of property 'controls' are incompatible.
    Type '{ name: FormControl<(control: AbstractControl<any, any>) => ValidationErrors>; }' is not assignable to type '{ name: FormControl<string>; }'.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 14.0.2
Node: 16.14.0
Package Manager: npm 8.5.1 
OS: linux x64

Angular: 14.0.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1400.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular   14.0.2
@angular-devkit/core            14.0.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      14.0.2
@schematics/angular             14.0.2
rxjs                            7.5.5
typescript                      4.6.4
```


### Anything else?

title: `canMatch` check throws `NullInjectorError` for a guard provided at the route level

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

There is the `NullInjectorError` if we try to use the `CanMatch` guard that is provided at the route level:

```ts
export class Guard implements CanMatch {
  canMatch(): boolean {
    return true;
  }
}

export const appRoutes: Route[] = [
  {
    path: 'foo',
    component: FooComponent,
    // error
    canMatch: [Guard],
    providers: [Guard],
  },
];
```

If we try to use e.g. `CanActivate` guard that is provided at the route level, it will be properly injected:

```ts
export const appRoutes: Route[] = [
  {
    path: 'foo',
    component: FooComponent,
    // works
    canActivate: [Guard],
    providers: [Guard],
  },
];
```

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(AppModule)[Guard -> Guard -> Guard]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for Guard!
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(AppModule)[Guard -> Guard -> Guard]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for Guard!
    at NullInjector.get (core.mjs:9091:27)
    at R3Injector.get (core.mjs:9258:33)
    at R3Injector.get (core.mjs:9258:33)
    at R3Injector.get (core.mjs:9258:33)
    at NgModuleRef.get (core.mjs:22413:33)
    at router.mjs:3313:32
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at runCanMatchGuards (router.mjs:3312:42)
    at matchWithChecks (router.mjs:3340:12)
    at ApplyRedirects.matchSegmentAgainstRoute (router.mjs:3674:16)
    at resolvePromise (zone.js:1211:31)
    at resolvePromise (zone.js:1165:17)
    at zone.js:1278:17
    at _ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone.js:406:31)
    at Object.onInvokeTask (core.mjs:26501:33)
    at _ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone.js:405:60)
    at Zone.runTask (zone.js:178:47)
    at drainMicroTaskQueue (zone.js:585:35)
    at ZoneTask.invokeTask [as invoke] (zone.js:491:21)
    at invokeTask (zone.js:1648:18)
```

title: Retrieve all route segments configuration by URL

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
**Note**: This issue was recreated from the discussion as we over eagerly converted it to a discussion before we had confirmed our process for potentially using discussions for this type of issue. I have moved it to back to an issue, and you can see the original issue with comments at https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/15750.
Originally posted by **smnbbrv** April 4, 2017 **I'm submitting a ...** (check one with "x") ``` [ ] bug report => search github for a similar issue or PR before submitting [x] feature request [ ] support request => Please do not submit support request here, instead see https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#question ``` **Current behavior** There is no clear way to get the configuration, see http://stackoverflow.com/q/43143621/1990451. Given a URL, e.g. `/path/path2/path3/123;sdf=df` and a routes configuration: { path: 'path', data: { g: 'h' }, children: [ { path: 'path2', data: { c: 'd' }, children: [ { path: 'something', component: TestpageComponent, data: { a: 'b' } }, { path: 'path3/create', component: TestpageComponent, data: { b: 'c' } }, { path: 'path3/:id', component: TestpageComponent, data: { b: 'c' } }, ] } ] }, It would be useful to find an actual configuration for all the segments in order to e.g. get a result set of all `data` parameters on all levels (each segment of the url). It is possible to split the URL to the segments by e.g. console.log(this.router.parseUrl(url)); or to be more precise console.log(this.router.parseUrl(url).root.children['primary'].segments); which will return [{"path":"path","parameters":{}},{"path":"path2","parameters":{}},{"path":"and","parameters":{}},{"path":"123","parameters":{"sdf":"df"}}] So, splitting the URL into segments is not a problem. However it does not provide the configuration for each segment. One can get the actual configuration for all the routes with console.log(this.router.config); It's possible to go with the parsed segments through the configuration tree and resolve the branch (and it's not that complicated actually), but it can cause troubles e.g. while resolving `:id` against `create` segment. So, it would be cool to use the *router's* way of resolving the configuration. **Expected behavior** I would expect a method on a `Router` service that returns an array of all the configurations available for a given URL. E.g. router.configurationByUrl('/path/path2/path3/123;sdf=df') // returns [ // { path: 'path', data: { g: 'h' }, children: [...] }, // { path: 'path2', data: { c: 'd' }, children: [...] }, // { path: 'path3/:id', component: TestpageComponent, data: { b: 'c' } } //], **Minimal reproduction of the problem with instructions** **What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?** Imagine I have a 50% of the URLs protected by some guard (e.g. only logged in users could go there) and other 50% is not protected (displayed for everybody). So, on the navigation menu level (outside of the `router-outlet`) I want to display only the links which are relevant for the current user, so I need to know which routes are protected by the guard. Guards / data / whatever is just a particular case of the problem. **Please tell us about your environment:** * **Angular version:** 2.0.X / 4.0.X * **Browser:** [all] * **Language:** [all] * **Node (for AoT issues):** `node --version` = X

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Standalone Components that are imported in an NgModule but not used in any template (and not referenced somewhere else) are still part of the production bundle.

body:
### Description

This page is marked for archive :

https://angular.io/guide/user-input#key-event-filtering-with-keyenter

This is EXACTLY the sort of page - providing good practical examples and advice as opposed to theoretical reference - that Angular needs more of - not less!

The alternative suggested is not useful in the least!

title: Style binding + style animation + non-reused route + emulated encapsulation breaks route transition animation

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

animations

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

**Prerequisites**
A container component is displaying a child component in a router outlet. The same child component class is used to display multiple pages of content, so to display a page slide as a route transition animation, route reuse is disabled. The content of the child component can be mouse-dragged (which sets its position with a style binding) and animates back to an initial position on doubleclick.

**Bug**
During the route transition animation, style bindings for the `:leave`-ing component are unexpectedly deactivated, resulting in an undesired jump in content position.

**Workaround**
Switching the child component view encapsulation to shadow dom works around the bug.

title: zone.js Mocha patch regression in v0.11.5

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

The patch for `it.skip` disappeared in v0.11.5.

zone.js v0.11.4, `fesm2015/zone-testing.js`, line 1061:

```javascript
    global.xit = global.xspecify = Mocha.it.skip = function () {
        return mochaOriginal.it.skip.apply(this, wrapTestInZone(arguments));
    };
```

zone.js v0.11.5, line 1061:

```javascript
    global.xit = global.xspecify = function () {
        return mochaOriginal.it.skip.apply(this, wrapTestInZone(arguments));
    };
```

The function [is still part of the Mocha API](https://mochajs.org/#inclusive-tests) and shouldn't have been removed.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

title: Content projection for templates

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Issue that requests a new feature

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request? core ### Description [Content projection](https://angular.io/guide/content-projection) is an amazing feature, but it [has no elegant support](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51948301/using-ng-content-in-ng-template/) for `ng-template`. Such feature exists in many other template engines ( [Twig](https://twig.symfony.com/doc/3.x/tags/macro.html), [Jinja2](https://docs-python.ru/packages/modul-jinja2-python/takoe-makrosy-shablonov-jinja2/), [Nunjucks](https://mozilla.github.io/nunjucks/templating.html#macro) etc.) and very handy, as makes templates bit less verbose and allow to follow the [DRY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself) principle which increase overall productivity. Technically, such feature brings capability to operate with templates like with a [higher order functions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higher-order_function), and allow to reuse and compose them pretty simple. ### Proposed solution ### Option 1: `` component ```html World ! Hello ``` ### Option 2: `*ngTemplateOutletContent` directive ```html World ! Hello ``` ### Option 3: Both component and direcive Option 2 prevent appearing of component related nodes in DOM and makes it more clean, but Option 1 semantics looks great. So would be nice to have both on developer choice. ### Proof of concept Proof of concept on [StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/ng-template-content?file=src%2Fmain.ts) for Angular 14. Proposed solution is based on top of [access to private fields](https://stackblitz.com/edit/ng-template-content?file=src%2Fng-macro%2Fng-macro.directive.ts) (see `getMacroTemplateContext` function), so **required implementation on core level**. ### Alternatives considered Technically [feature](https://stackoverflow.com/a/56958107/1543705) already supported by core. But on practice: - Implementation is not obvious and straightforward; - Html markup too verbose and destroy sematic; This makes feature usage too complicated or even not possible. For sure, components itself do the stuff excellent. But for complex components create additional components just to decrease local markup complexity - it's just brings an additional complexity to the whole application.
